heading.title: Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 (NSW)
COURT SUPPRESSION AND NON-PUBLICATION ORDERS ACT 2010 (NSW)

leg:info.leg:officialname: COURT SUPPRESSION AND NON-PUBLICATION ORDERS ACT 2010 (NSW)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [60,120] s 6 Safeguarding public interest in open justice

leg:heading.title: Safeguarding public interest in open justice

p.text: In deciding whether to make a suppression order or non-publication order, a court must take into account that a primary objective of the administration of justice is to safeguard the public interest in open justice.

level.toc-caption: [60,120.5] Publication of details of judicial proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [60,120.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71.

heading.title: Publication of details of judicial proceedings

p.text: Proceedings which take place in open court are ordinarily freely reportable. So long as the report is fair, accurate and published in good faith, it will not involve either contempt or defamation: R v Evening News; Ex parte Hobbs [1925] 2 KB 158 ; R v Kray (1969) 53 Cr App R 412 at 414; Re Consolidated Press Ltd; Ex parte Terrill (1937) 37 SR (NSW) 255 at 257; 54 WN (NSW) 106 ; Cassidy v Mercury Newspaper Pty Ltd [1968] Tas SR 198. But the freedom to publish matters which occur in open court is not unlimited. The publication of rejected evidence, or of matters given in the absence of a jury, may constitute contempt: Attorney-General (UK) v Leveller Magazine Ltd [1979] AC 440 at 450; [1979] 1 All ER 745; [1979] 2 WLR 247; (1979) 68 Cr App Rep 342 ; R v Horsham Justices; Ex parte Farquharson [1982] QB 762 at 791; [1982] 2 All ER 269; [1982] 2 WLR 430; (1981) 76 Cr App Rep 87 ; R v Border Television Ltd; Ex parte A-G (1978) 68 Cr App R 375; Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280; [1982] 1 All ER 532; [1982] 2 WLR 338 .

Apart from those situations, the court does have the power, as CPA s 71 and the specific provisions in ss 4 , 5 and 7 of the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act (CN&NPO Act) make clear, to restrict access to evidence in the proceedings and to order non-publication of details of the proceedings. The specifically permissible (but not exhaustive) grounds for making suppression orders are set out in s 8 of the CN&NPO Act.

The emphasis in the many authorities decided under the general law before the CN&NPO Act tended to characterise as exceptional the circumstances in which orders could be made suppressing disclosure of the proceedings or evidence: Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417 at 438, 453; [1911–13] All ER Rep 1 ; Grofam Pty Ltd v Macauley (No 2) (1994) 48 FCR 573; 121 ALR 22; BC9405921 (refusal to order restricted access to evidence where a prospective witness was likely, in the absence of such an order, to claim privilege against incrimination). The declaration of “primary objective” in the present section evokes reliance on a similar approach. However it is potentially significant that the permissible grounds set out in s 8 of the CN&NPO Act all refer to the “necessity” of the order, rather than to any characterisation of the circumstances as either special or exceptional. Furthermore the particular criterion that applies to disclosure in relation to proceedings involving sexual offences, is that of “undue distress or embarrassment”. That criterion plainly permits (indeed requires) an impressionistic assessment quite different from any characterisation of the circumstances as relevantly out of the ordinary. See R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1101; BC201107144 at [25]ff (“where the application of the power to make a non-publication order conflicts with the principle of open justice the test of necessity must be applied with strictness”: [27]) and [60,130.2] below for discussion of the application of the principle of open justice.
A court may, by making a suppression order or non-publication order on grounds permitted by this Act, prohibit or restrict the publication or other disclosure of:

information tending to reveal the identity of or otherwise concerning any party to or witness in proceedings before the court or any person who is related to or otherwise associated with any party to or witness in proceedings before the court, or
information that comprises evidence, or information about evidence, given in proceedings before the court.

level.toc-caption: [60,125.5] Orders that witnesses or parties be referred to by pseudonyms

heading.title: Orders that witnesses or parties be referred to by pseudonyms

p.text: Sometimes statutory provisions may require parties to be referred to by initials or pseudonyms: eg Victims Compensation Fund Corp v GM (2004) 60 NSWLR 310; 148 A Crim R 301; [2004] NSWCA 185; BC200403610 (sexual assault victims — Crimes Act 1900 s 578A ); Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 s 15A(1) . Apart from any such specific statutory provisions a court may order that a witness or a party be referred to by a pseudonym. Examples of situations where orders of this kind have been made include:

witnesses or parties concerned with illicit sexual relations: Witness v Marsden (2000) 49 NSWLR 429; [2000] NSWCA 52; BC200001106 (jailed prisoner giving evidence of underage sexual relations); Chambers v James Cook University of Northern Australia (No 1) (1995) 16 IR 121 (use of pseudonyms to identify parties in sexual harassment litigation); Department of Community Services v ABC (NSWSC, McLelland CJ, 2265/96, 4 June 1996, unreported, BC9602181)(inherent power to protect identity of minors who are victims of sexual abuse);

a witness or party in proceedings relating to a stigmatising illness or condition: E v Australian Red Cross Society (1991) 27 FCR 310 at 313; 99 ALR 601; (1991) ASC 56-029; BC9103001 (AIDS plaintiff); TK v Australian Red Cross Society (1989) 1 WAR 335 (plaintiffs might be reasonably deterred from bringing proceedings because of embarrassment that they might suffer if their condition were known generally); BT v Oei [1999] NSWSC 1082; BC9907209 (HIV plaintiff);

witnesses or parties in proceedings involving claims of blackmail or extortion: John Fairfax Group Pty Ltd (recs and mgrs apptd) v Local Court of NSW (1991) 26 NSWLR 131; 26 ALD 471; 59 A Crim R 68 (extortion victims); R v Socialist Worker Printers and Publishers Ltd; Ex parte A-G [1975] QB 637 at 649; [1975] 1 All ER 142; [1974] 3 WLR 801 (blackmail);

evidence given by national security operatives or other informers, especially police informers: Taylor v A-G [1975] 2 NZLR 675 ; G v Australian Broadcasting Commission (NSWSC, Rath J, 6 June 1979, unreported); G v Day [1982] 1 NSWLR 24 at 42 ; A v Hayden (No 2) (1984) 156 CLR 532; 56 ALR 82; 59 ALJR 6; BC8400488 (national intelligence agency operatives); Cain v Glass (No 2) (1985) 3 NSWLR 230 at 246 (police informers); Luxottica Retail Australia Pty Ltd v Specsavers [2010] NSWSC 54; BC201000436 (commercial proceedings involving witnesses engaged to monitor retail trading practices); and

a person seeking to restrain publication of illegally obtained evidence: Taylor v A-G, above; John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Doe (1995) 37 NSWLR 81 at 90; 130 ALR 488; 80 A Crim R 414; BC9504809 (accused person seeking to restrain illegal publication of telephone interception); — but compare Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Jones (1985) 2 NSWLR 47 (refusal to order non-disclosure of the identity of a defendant to civil contempt proceedings).

fertility cases — to ensure that the child did not later happen upon circumstances discussed in the case: Sydney South West Area Health Service v MD (2009) 260 ALR 702; [2009] NSWCA 343; BC200909477 at [46]–[47]; Ax v Stern [2008] VSC 400; BC200808682 ;

necessary to protect a party’s psychological safety: X v Sydney Children’s Hospitals Specialty Network [2011] NSWSC 1272; BC201108905 (unopposed application, court satisfied that pseudonym order necessary).

Where such an order has been made, subsequent publication of the true identity of the person concerned may constitute an offence and may be punished as an offence or as a contempt of court: see CN&NPO Act ss 16 and 17 ; R v Socialist Worker Printers and Publishers Ltd; Ex parte A-G [1975] QB 637; [1975] 1 All ER 142; [1974] 3 WLR 801 ; Attorney-General (UK) v Leveller Magazine Ltd [1979] AC 440; [1979] 1 All ER 745; [1979] 2 WLR 247; (1979) 68 Cr App Rep 342 .

The potentially alternative sanctions may involve different liability criteria. Reckless disclosure will constitute an offence under s 16 of the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010. Whether or not the disclosure also constitutes contempt will depend upon the circumstances and, in particular, whether the nature of the publication is such as to threaten the administration of justice either in the particular case or in relation to cases which may be brought in the future: Attorney-General (UK) v Leveller Magazine Ltd, above at AC 465. Such a threat would not be held to exist unless there was a proper connection between the non-disclosure order and the requirements of secrecy necessary for the proper conduct of the proceedings.

In relation to protection of privacy generally see Supreme Court “Identity theft prevention and anonymisation policy” (Mar 2010) at http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/agdbasev7wr/ supremecourt/documents/pdf/policy identity_theft_prevention.pdf .

Section 7 permits orders to be made to prohibit disclosure of any information given in proceedings that would tend to identify a witness or party or any person who is related to or otherwise associated with any witness or party in proceedings. The section, at least when read with the offence provision in s 16 of the CS&NPO Act, indicates that a suppression order would relevantly affect persons other than those who are formally parties to, and witnesses in, the proceedings: R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248 at [22]–[25].

This contrasts with the view under the general law that it would not usually be a justifiable exercise of discretion to make orders which purport to prohibit publication of the identity of a person who was neither a party to, nor a witness in, the proceedings: John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd v Police Tribunal (NSW) (1986) 5 NSWLR 465 . In United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 , it was held that the District Court of New South Wales had no such power. In John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; 50 ACSR 380 ; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 a District Court judge made orders suppressing the publication of a verdict relating to breaches of the Corporations Law. The order was directed to the “electronic and/or print media”. It was held that the District Court had no power to make a non-publication order directed only to persons unrelated to the proceedings (eg the media).

There was the further related consideration under the general law as to whether publication by a third person who was neither a party nor a witness would necessarily constitute contempt. It may do so if it had a tendency to threaten the due administration of justice (Reid v Howard (1993) 31 NSWLR 298 ; CCOM Pty Ltd v Jiejing Pty Ltd (1992) 36 FCR 524 at 531; BC9203610 ) but such a tendency is not shown merely by establishing that the publication was contrary to an order of the court: Attorney-General (NSW) v Mayas Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 342 .
Where an order has been made under CN&NPO Act s 7 contravention constitutes an offence. It is punishable either as contempt, or as an offence under the Act: see CN&NPO Act s 16 .

level.toc-caption: [60,125.15] Prohibition of publication of court orders

heading.title: Prohibition of publication of court orders

p.text: The power conferred by s 7 of the CN&NPO Act does not expressly include suppression of the orders made in the proceedings. Even assuming that such a separate statutory power was intended to be conferred (as distinct from merely preserved — by virtue of ss 4 and 5 of the CN&NPO Act) it will be a wholly exceptional case in which the power to prevent disclosure will extend to prohibit disclosure of the court's orders and reasons for judgment.

If it is absolutely necessary that some material not be disclosed then the court should structure its orders and reasons so as to permit them, or parts of them, to be published without jeopardising the legitimate interests of the parties: David Syme & Co Ltd v General Motors Holden Ltd [1984] 2 NSWLR 294 . Where proceedings have been conducted in open court it is not proper to prohibit either the publication of those orders nor of the terms of any settlement which they may reflect: S Hoffnung & Co Ltd v Hesky [1977] 2 NSWLR 669 ; cf National Bank of Australasia Ltd v Solar (1977) 14 ACTR 1; 28 FLR 372 . Orders for the non-publication of the fact that verdicts of guilty have been returned is unlikely to be justified to ensure a fair trial in a subsequent case (eg in back to back cases), adjournments and stays will ordinarily be sufficient to ensure a fair trial: see John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; 50 ACSR 380 ; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 (orders were made in the District Court suppressing the publication of a verdict relating to breaches of the Corporations Law — held that the District Court did not have an express power to make a non-publication order, and had no implied power to order non-publication of a verdict).

The suppression order power in CN&NPO Act s 7 is not limited to evidence given in the proceedings. It includes the power to suppress the publication of other information about the parties, witnesses or the likely evidence in the proceedings. In relation to “pre-hearing” suppression of information this power has a particular application to criminal proceedings and the suppression of information that might prejudice the fair trial of the proceedings: R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 ; R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248.
The power to suppress publication has been interpreted to permit orders requiring internet publishers to “take down” information that internet accessible: R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248.

Through the use of twitter, blogs, social networking sites and other websites, information can be published to a large audience without knowledge of or regard for the legal restrictions on such publications. See “Twitter, suppression and the courts” Internet Law Bulletin 15(3) July 2012 pp 42–45 (T Griffith, K Kossian, T Kowalczuk): Twitter is changing the way court proceedings are reported — facilitating real time information direct from court proceedings. The article refers to Swedish Judicial Authority v Assange [2010] EWHC 3473 (Admin) 2010 WL 5093971 (Julian Assange bail proceedings in the UK in Dec 2010) where the use of twitter was expressly allowed to report proceedings. The Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales has issued a Practice Guidance Note: “The use of live text-based forms of communication (including twitter) from court for the purposes of fair and accurate reporting”.

A New Zealand District Court ruled in 2010 that content published on a blog, revealing names that were subject to a court suppression order, was in breach of the Court order, despite arguments that the website was not based in New Zealand and that the names were coded and disguised: Police v Slater [2010] CRN 004028329-9833 (unreported, Harvey J, 14 September 2010); C Ford “Blogs and the publication of names subject to suppression” (Privacy Aware Vol 9 No 3 Spring 2010).

An order under s 7 is an interlocutory order: see also s 13 ; Welker v Rinehart (No 6) [2012] NSWSC 160; BC201201270 at [17]. There is no absolute bar to a further application being made in the proceedings. Conversely no principle of procedural estoppel applies to any order. An order under s 7 is similar to an order under s 50 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth) (dealing with prohibition on publication of evidence) which the High Court held was interlocutory in Hogan v Australian Crime Commission (2010) 240 CLR 651; 267 ALR 12; [2010] HCA 21; BC201004004 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [60,130] s 8 Grounds for making an order

p.text: A court may make a suppression order or non-publication order on one or more of the following grounds:
the order is necessary to prevent prejudice to the proper administration of justice,
the order is necessary to prevent prejudice to the interests of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory in relation to national or international security,
the order is necessary to protect the safety of any person,
the order is necessary to avoid causing undue distress or embarrassment to a party to or witness in criminal proceedings involving an offence of a sexual nature (including an act of indecency),
it is otherwise necessary in the public interest for the order to be made and that public interest significantly outweighs the public interest in open justice.
A suppression order or non-publication order must specify the ground or grounds on which the order is made.
Legislation cited in [60,130.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 8(1).
Each of the CS&NPO Act s 8(1) grounds for making a suppression order requires the court’s satisfaction about what is “necessary”.

The term “necessary” does not have the meaning of “essential”, rather it is to be “subjected to the touchstone of reasonableness”: Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (NSW) (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 452; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . The concept as to what reasonably is necessary is to be approached in a common sense way: State Drug Crime Commission (NSW) v Chapman (1987) 12 NSWLR 447 at 452; 33 A Crim R 376 .

Any assessment of what is reasonably “necessary” will depend on the nature of the information and the circumstances and purpose of the proposed suppression. In BUSB v R (2011) 80 NSWLR 170; 248 FLR 368; [2011] NSWCCA 39; BC201102854 at [33]ff, Spigelman CJ addressed the test of necessity in the context of a screening order and said where the test impinged on a fundamental principle of the administration of criminal justice, in that case the right to confront accusers, “the test must be applied with a higher level of strictness”. A similar level of strictness applies in determining whether proceedings should be conducted in the absence of the public: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Ryde Local Court (2005) 62 NSWLR 512; 220 ALR 248; [2005] NSWCA 101; BC200501968 at [40]–[45] per Spigelman CJ; O’Shane v Burwood Local Courts (NSW) (2007) 178 A Crim R 392; [2007] NSWSC 1300; BC200709920 at [34].

However some of the criteria in CS&NPO Act s 8(1) involve issues of personal safety, “undue distress” and “public interest”. These evaluative criteria are less amenable to the application of an inflexibly strict assessment of what is “necessary” in the particular case. Particularly is this the case where suppression orders are sought for the purpose of avoiding prejudice to the fair trial of impending criminal proceedings: Fairfax Digital Australia & New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 at [46].

An application for a suppression order must be supported by material that provides a proper basis for a reasonably formed conclusion that it is necessary to make a non-publication or suppression order. Mere belief that the order is necessary is insufficient: R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1101; BC201107144 and R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 (internet “take down” order — temporary suppression of evidence until conclusion of criminal jury trial proceedings — apprehended prejudice to fair trial).

level.toc-caption: [60,130.5] Prejudice to the administration of justice

p.text: Legislation cited in [60,130.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71.

heading.title: Prejudice to the administration of justice

p.text: Ordinarily judicial proceedings are conducted in public: see CPA s 71 and CS&NPO Act s 6 . Where material has been put into evidence in the course of proceedings conducted in public, there is a general principle favouring their disclosure: see [31.11.5] and Practice Notes [SC Gen 2] and DC (Civil) 11. The otherwise confidential nature of evidence given in public proceedings (whether or not that confidentiality relates to personal or commercial matters) will not usually justify an order suppressing further disclosure of the evidence on the ground that its suppression is “necessary” to prevent prejudice to the proper administration of justice: Hogan v Australian Crime Commission (2010) 240 CLR 651; 84 ALJR 479; [2010] HCA 21; BC201004004 at [30]–[33], [38] (contentious evidence asserting a suggestion of taxation fraud); Rinehart v Welker (2012) 285 ALR 191; [2012] NSWCA 1; BC201200118 at [50]–[55] (proceedings involving a dispute between members of an exceptionally wealthy family).

In considering orders designed to protect the proper administration of justice, it is desirable to distinguish between constraints on publication of material disclosed in court proceedings and publication of material having no connection with court proceedings except its capacity to affect current or future proceedings: Fairfax Digital Australia & New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 at [51] (an order not directed to any persons specifically but having a geographic operation purporting to prevent the publication of material referring to any other criminal proceedings in which the respondents were parties or witnesses, set aside).

level.toc-caption: [60,130.10] “order necessary to prevent prejudice to the proper administration of justice”: s 8(1)(a)

heading.title: “order necessary to prevent prejudice to the proper administration of justice”: s 8(1)(a)

p.text: In John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; 50 ACSR 380; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 Spigelman CJ at [19] accepted that there were exceptions to the principle of open justice but described them as few and strictly limited. The suppression order grounds set out in CS&NPO Act s 8 at least potentially enlarge the situations in which orders may be made, even though the primary objective remains that of safeguarding the public interest in open justice: CS&NPO Act s 6.
Examples of suppression or non-publication orders made on the grounds of prejudice to the proper administration of justice:

Da Silva v R (No 2) [2012] NSWCCA 106; BC201203554 : order granted for the non-publication of evidence given in proceedings — publication would indirectly reveal police methodology with regard to the value placed on specific types of information ; may create an expectation that a specific amount of money might be paid for information.

Bissett v Deputy State Coroner [2011] NSWSC 1182; BC201110396 : order refused for publication of transcripts of interviews; order granted for non-publication of contents of DVD (visual contents likely to have significantly greater impact);

Rinehart v Welker [2011] NSWCA 345; BC201108758 : order granted prohibited the disclosure by publication or otherwise of any information as to the relief claimed or any pleading, the Summary of Argument, submissions, the draft Notice of Appeal, evidence or argument filed, read or given in these proceedings, and including the contents of the red book, blue book, black book and orange book but not including the Summons seeking Leave to Appeal or the pronounced or published judgment of Tobias AJA. Publication of material filed in the appeal proceedings would negate the purpose of the confidentiality provisions of the Trust Deed between the parties and would circumvent the rights of the applicants to have disputes resolved by confidential mediation or arbitration;

Welker v Rinehart (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 1238; BC201109935 : Interim suppression order (on grounds in s 8(1)(a)) made pending application for leave to appeal — failure to grant suppression order would render arguable appeal nurgatory and undermine the claimed right to confidentiality in the event the Court of Appeal upheld the appeal;

R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248: non-publication order made in relation to information revealing that the accused was serving imprisonment for previous offences and was the subject of Underbelly TV program — information likely to be damaging to the prospects of a fair trial.

Nichols v Singleton Council [2011] NSWSC 946; BC201106424 (Schmidt J): Suppression order made — to prevent prejudice to the proper administration of justice and in the public interest — complaint made to Council — complainant’s name inadvertently disclosed — competing public interests — complainant’s name suppressed.

In Fairfax Digital Australian & New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 , Basten JA ( Bathurst CJ and Whealey JA agreeing) at [36] characterises the primary purpose of all the grounds set out in s 8(1) except the first as permitting a court to protect witnesses and parties in proceedings before it from disclosure of information about them to the general public. Only para (a) appears to extend to the protection of the jury from inflammatory or irrelevant material while the proceedings are on foot. At [64] the question is put as to “whether novel problems are created with respect to the fairness of criminal trials where there is significant material available on the Internet.”

In criminal trials concern has been expressed, and often argued in support of a suppression order, that the fair trial of an accused may be jeopardised if prejudicial information about them came to the attention of jury members. In the ordinary case juries will be instructed to confine themselves to the evidence in the proceedings. The jury will typically be told not to conduct internet searches of their own, and they will be warned that such searches constitute a criminal offence (under s 68C of the Jury Act). Some courts have held that the prospect of a jury’s non-compliance is sufficiently unlikely that further suppression of pre-trial information is not necessary: News Digital Media Pty Ltd v Mokbel (2010) 30 VR 248; 211 A Crim R 292; [2010] VSCA 51; BC201010595 at [94]. Other cases have held that the risk of prejudice to the prospect of a fair trial is sufficient to justify a suppression order being made: see R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248 at [26]ff (the s appreciable risk of juror enquiry and the degree of risk to the fairness of the impending trial sufficed to establish that it was necessary to suppress publication of the accused’s prior murder convictions); R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 at [54].

heading.title: Utility or futility of such orders

p.text: The issue of utility or futility of such orders (especially in relation to the Internet) is often raised in argument. For example, removal of information or articles published (or archived) by mainstream media organisations would not have the effect of removing information found on Wikipedia. It has been argued that the more appropriate persons against whom such orders should be made or directed are the proprietors of the search engines by means of which access to any material uploaded to the Internet can be found. In R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248 at [40] RS Hulme J says that as “I apprehend the Act, a non-publication order made in unqualified terms would immediately bind not only the media organisations … but also organisations such as the owners of Wikipedia, Google and other search engines but they would commit no offence until notified of the order and guilty conduct otherwise constituting contempt of court and breach of s 16(1) .” In R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 at [44] Price J notes: “the inability to remove all offending material does not necessarily lead to the conclusion that the provision of the relief sought would be futile.”

level.toc-caption: [60,130.20] “order necessary to protect the safety of any person”: s 8(1)(c)

heading.title: “order necessary to protect the safety of any person”: s 8(1)(c)

p.text: A likelihood of increased media attention, and apprehension that it may increase the possibility of kidnapping or extortion, does not constitute a threat to a person’s safety and does not suffice to establish that a suppression order is “necessary”: Welker v Rinehart (No 5) [2012] NSWSC 45; BC201200352 at [17]; Welker v Rinehart (No 6) [2012] NSWSC 160; BC201201270 at [55] (order refused — except to the extent of “de-identification” of personal details consistent with the court’s anonymisation policy).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [60,135] s 9 Procedure for making an order

p.text: A court may make a suppression order or non-publication order on its own initiative or on the application of:
a party to the proceedings concerned, or
any other person considered by the court to have a sufficient interest in the making of the order.
Each of the following persons is entitled to appear and be heard by the court on an application for a suppression order or non-publication order:
the applicant for the order,
a party to the proceedings concerned,
the Government (or an agency of the Government) of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory,
a news media organisation,
any other person who, in the court’s opinion, has a sufficient interest in the question of whether a suppression order or non-publication order should be made.
A suppression order or non-publication order may be made at any time during proceedings or after proceedings have concluded.
A suppression order or non-publication order may be made subject to such exceptions and conditions as the court thinks fit and specifies in the order.

A suppression order or non-publication order must specify the information to which the order applies with sufficient particularity to ensure that the order is limited to achieving the purpose for which the order is made.
An order must contain the following information:
duration of order (either by reference to a fixed or ascertainable period or by reference to the occurrence of a specified future event): s 12(1) and (3) .

In certain circumstances, it may be necessary to take appropriate steps to ensure the media is notified of either a suppression or non-publication order. In the Supreme Court and District Court this is done by the associate notifying the Supreme Court’s Public Information Office.

If an application is made to a court for a suppression order or non-publication order, the court may, without determining the merits of the application, make the order as an interim order to have effect, subject to revocation by the court, until the application is determined.
If an order is made as an interim order, the court must determine the application as a matter of urgency.

Section 10 has been included in the Act to cater for the possibility that it is not possible to hear argument in relation to whether a suppression or non-publication order should be made. In those circumstances, s 10 gives the court power to make an interim order that should last only for so long as it is necessary for the court to hear argument on the merits: Welker v Rinehart (No 5) [2012] NSWSC 45; BC201200352 (application for interim non-publication order based on s 10 refused). In Welker v Rinehart (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 1238; BC201109935 an interim suppression order was made by Brereton J pending an application for leave to appeal upon the grounds referred to in s 8(1)(a). The order was to have effect, subject to revocation by the court, until the expiration of 7 days from the date on which the written reasons for judgment were published on the court’s website, and thereafter (if a summons for leave to appeal had been files) until the determination of that application.
A suppression order or non-publication order applies only to the disclosure or publication of information in a place where the order applies, as specified in the order.
A suppression order or non-publication order is not limited to applying in New South Wales and can be made to apply anywhere in the Commonwealth.

However, an order is not to be made to apply outside New South Wales unless the court is satisfied that having the order apply outside New South Wales is necessary for achieving the purpose for which the order is made.
A suppression order or non-publication order operates for the period decided by the court and specified in the order.
In deciding the period for which an order is to operate, the court is to ensure that the order operates for no longer than is reasonably necessary to achieve the purpose for which it is made.
The period for which an order operates may be specified by reference to a fixed or ascertainable period or by reference to the occurrence of a specified future event.

The court is obliged to ensure that an order operates for no longer than is necessary to achieve the purpose for which it was made. Such orders are often made “until further order”. In X v Sydney Children’s Hospitals Specialty Network [2011] NSWSC 1272; BC201108905 the order was made “until seven days after the close of evidence in the present proceedings, subject to further order of the court” at [18]. In R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 the order was made “until after the trial and verdicts in the matter … or further order.”
The court that made a suppression order or non-publication order may review the order on the court’s own initiative or on the application of a person who is entitled to apply for the review.
Each of the following persons is entitled to apply for and to appear and be heard by the court on the review of an order under this section:
the applicant for the order,
a party to the proceedings in connection with which the order was made,
the Government (or an agency of the Government) of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory,
a news media organisation,
any other person who, in the court’s opinion, has a sufficient interest in the question of whether a suppression order or non-publication order should have been made or should continue to operate.
On a review, the court may confirm, vary or revoke the order and may in addition make any other order that the court may make under this Act.

Section 13 operates differently from s 14 in that s 13 is confined to a review by the original court which granted the order: Fairfax Digital Australia and New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 at [5] .
With leave of the appellate court, an appeal lies against:
a decision of a court (the original court) to make or not to make a suppression order or non-publication order, or
a decision by the original court on the review of, or a decision by the original court not to review, a suppression order or non-publication order made by the court.
The appellate court for an appeal under this section is the court to which appeals lie against final judgments or orders of the original court or, if there is no such court, the Supreme Court.
Each of the following persons is entitled to appear and be heard on an appeal under this section:
the applicant for the suppression order or non-publication order,
a party to the proceedings in which the order or decision subject to appeal was made,
the Government (or an agency of the Government) of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory,
a news media organisation,
any other person who, in the appellate court’s opinion, has a sufficient interest in the decision that is the subject of appeal.

On an appeal under this section, the appellate court may confirm, vary or revoke the order or decision subject to the appeal and may make any order or decision under this Act that could have been made in the first instance.

An appeal under this section is to be by way of rehearing, and fresh evidence or evidence in addition to, or in substitution for, the evidence given on the making of the decision may be given on the appeal.

If judgments or orders of the original court are subject to review by another court (rather than appeal to another court), this section provides for a review of the original court’s decisions instead of an appeal and in such a case references in this section to an appeal are to be read as references to a review.

Section 14 deals with an appeal by leave, either in respect of the order of the original court or the order of that court on a review: Fairfax Digital Australia and New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 at [5] . Where the impugned orders are interlocutory orders made in the District Court in the exercise of its criminal jurisdiction, an appeal pursuant to s 14(2) lies to the Court of Criminal Appeal and not to the Court of Appeal. The hearing on the appeal is a hearing de novo: Fairfax Digital Australia and New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim at [6], [17]. Section 14(6) is not dealing with a review made by the original court under s 13 . The word “review”, in s 14(6) , refers to an alternative to a statutory appeal and not to the exercise by the Supreme Court of its supervisory jurisdiction: Fairfax Digital Australia and New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim at [20].

A suppression order does not prevent a person from disclosing information if the disclosure is not by publication and is in the course of performing functions or duties or exercising powers in a public official capacity:
in connection with the conduct of proceedings or the recovery or enforcement of any penalty imposed in proceedings, or
in compliance with any procedure adopted by a court for informing a news media organisation of the existence and content of a suppression order or non-publication order made by the court.

A person commits an offence if the person engages in conduct that constitutes a contravention of a suppression order or non-publication order and is reckless as to whether the conduct constitutes a contravention of a suppression order or non-publication order.
Maximum penalty: 1,000 penalty units or imprisonment for 12 months, or both, for an individual or 5,000 penalty units for a body corporate.
Conduct that constitutes an offence under this section may be punished as a contempt of court even though it could be punished as an offence.
Conduct that constitutes an offence under this section may be punished as an offence even though it could be punished as a contempt of court.
If conduct constitutes both an offence under this section and a contempt of court, the offender is not liable to be punished twice.

No offence is committed under s 16 , unless the person has had the order brought to their attention: Fairfax Digital Australia and New Zealand Pty Ltd v Ibrahim [2012] NSWCCA 125; BC201204176 at [66]–[70] .
